travail.meaning_1: noun: use of physical or mental energy; hard work; agony or anguish
travail.sentence_1: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.

irk.sentence_1: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

taxing.meaning_1: adjective: use to the limit; exhaust
taxing.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
taxing.sentence_1: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.

squander.meaning_1: verb: spend thoughtlessly; waste time, money, or an opportunity
squander.sentence_1: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.

brusquely.meaning_1: adverb: in a blunt, direct manner
brusquely.sentence_1: Not one for social pleasantries, the Chief of Staff would brusquely ask his subordinates anything he wanted, even coffee.

elude.sentence_1: While some physics concepts might elude newbies, with a little grit and a good teacher, almost anyone can develop a deep understanding of the subject.

goad.meaning_1: verb: urge on with unpleasant comments
goad.sentence_1: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.

obstinate.meaning_1: adjective: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent
obstinate.sentence_1: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.

impregnable.meaning_1: adjective: immune to attack; incapable of being tampered with
impregnable.sentence_1: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fortresses.

leery.meaning_1: adjective: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide
leery.sentence_1: Without checking his references and talking to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.

diligent.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks
diligent.sentence_1: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.

connive.meaning_1: verb: taking part in immoral and unethical plots
connive.sentence_1: With the help of the prince, the queen connived to overthrow the king.

ploy.meaning_1: noun: a clever plan to turn a situation to one's advantage
ploy.sentence_1: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.

malevolent.meaning_1: adjective: wishing or appearing to wish evil to others; arising from intense ill will or hatred
malevolent.sentence_1: Villains are known for their malevolent nature, oftentimes inflicting cruelty on others just for enjoyment.

perturb.meaning_1: verb: disturb in mind or cause to be worried or alarmed
perturb.sentence_1: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illness, he no longer lets the little trivialities, such as late mail, perturb him.

retract.meaning_1: verb: pull inward or towards a center; formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief, usually under pressure
retract.sentence_1: Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.

pastoral.meaning_1: adjective: relating to the countryside in a pleasant sense
pastoral.sentence_1: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of rural U.S. is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.

eke.meaning_1: verb: To live off meager resources, to scrape by
eke.sentence_1: Stranded in a cabin over the winter, Terry was able to eke out an existence on canned food.

tact.meaning_1: noun: consideration in dealing with others and avoiding giving offense
tact.sentence_1: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.

embellish.meaning_1: verb: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.; make more beautiful
embellish.sentence_1: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.

smug.meaning_1: adjective: marked by excessive complacency or self-satisfaction
smug.sentence_1: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.

credulity.sentence_1: Virginia's wide-eyed credulity as a five-year old was replaced by suspicion after she learned that Santa Claus didn't really exist.

placid.sentence_1: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

rash.meaning_1: adjective: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences; imprudently incurring risk
rash.sentence_1: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nighttime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.

complacent.meaning_1: adjective: contented to a fault with oneself or one's actions
complacent.sentence_1: After the water polo team won their sixth championship, they became complacent and didn't even make it to the playoffs the next year.

enmity.meaning_1: noun: a state of deep-seated ill-will
enmity.sentence_1: The rude remark Charles made toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

reservation.meaning_1: noun: an unstated doubt that prevents you from accepting something wholeheartedly
reservation.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
reservation.sentence_1: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C. but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.

discord.meaning_1: noun: lack of agreement or harmony
discord.sentence_1: Despite all their talented players, the team was filled with discord--some players refused to talk to others--and lost most of their games.

savvy.sentence_2: The student savvies the meaning of astrophysics with little effort.
savvy.meaning_2: verb: get the meaning of something
savvy.sentence_3: With his savvy business partner, the company was able to turn a profit within a year.
savvy.sentence_1: Although a great CEO, he did not have the political savvy to win the election.

maxim.meaning_1: noun: a short saying expressing a general truth
maxim.sentence_1: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300-page book to explain exactly what he means.

devolve.sentence_2: The dialogue between the two academics devolved into a downright bitter argument.
devolve.sentence_1: The company was full of managers known for devolving tasks to lower management, but never doing much work themselves.
devolve.meaning_1: verb: pass on or delegate to another

quip.sentence_2: When an old English teacher criticized Churchill for ending a sentence with a preposition, he quipped, "This is the kind of criticism up with which we will not put!"
quip.meaning_2: verb: to make a witty remark, to say in jest
quip.sentence_1: In one of the most famous quips about classical music, Mark Twain said: "Wagner's music is better than it sounds."
quip.meaning_1: noun: a witty saying or remark

exasperate.sentence_1: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

peevish.sentence_1: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

unprecedented.meaning_1: adjective: having never been done or known before; novel
unprecedented.sentence_1: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.

candidness.meaning_1: noun: the quality of being honest and straightforward in attitude and speech
candidness.sentence_1: Although I was unhappy that the relationship ended, I appreciated her candidness about why she was ready to move on from the relationship.

collusion.meaning_1: noun: agreement on a secret plot
collusion.sentence_1: Many have argued that Lee Harvey Oswald, JFK's assassin, was in collusion with other criminals; others maintain that Oswald was a lone gunman.

aphoristic.meaning_1: adjective: something that is concise and instructive of a general truth or principle
aphoristic.sentence_1: Sometimes I can't stand Nathan because he tries to impress everyone by being aphoristic, but he just states the obvious.

destitute.sentence_2: Now that the mine is closed, the town is destitute of any economic activity.
destitute.meaning_2: adjective: completely wanting or lacking (usually "destitute of")
destitute.sentence_1: Jean Valjean, is at first destitute, but through the grace of a priest, he makes something of his life.
destitute.meaning_1: adjective: poor enough to need help from others

presumption.sentence_2: The new neighbor quickly gained a reputation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several neighbors' homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.
presumption.meaning_2: noun: audacious (even arrogant) behavior that you have no right to
presumption.sentence_1: When Mr. Baker found out the family car was gone, he acted under the presumption that his rebellious son had taken the car, calling his son's phone and yelling at him; only later did Mr. Baker realize that Mrs. Baker had simply gone out to get her nails done.
presumption.meaning_1: noun: an assumption that is taken for granted

derogative.meaning_1: adjective: expressed as worthless or in negative terms
derogative.sentence_1: Never before have we seen a debate between two political candidates that was so derogative and filthy.

exemplify.sentence_2: Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.
exemplify.meaning_2: verb: clarify by giving an example of
exemplify.sentence_1: Lincoln exemplified the best of not only America, but also the potential greatness that exists within each person.

tout.meaning_1: verb: advertize in strongly positive terms; show off
tout.sentence_1: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research & Development division.

foible.meaning_1: noun: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
foible.sentence_1: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.

unseemly.meaning_1: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
unseemly.sentence_1: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.

steadfast.meaning_1: adjective: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable
steadfast.sentence_1: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.

serene.sentence_1: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

convoluted.sentence_1: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.

tarnish.meaning_1: verb: make dirty or spotty, as by exposure to air; also used metaphorically
tarnish.sentence_1: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.

impending.meaning_1: adjective: close in time; about to occur
impending.sentence_1: The impending doom of our world has been discussed and debated for 2000 years—maybe even longer.
